timeline.bodyText:
This needs to be conditional.
We don't want to perform this update if:
a) It's already been completed.
b) Another even newer config update has been completed.
timeline.author: tkaitchuck

replies.bodyText: Its been made conditional.
replies.author: anirudhkovuru

timeline.bodyText:
What if updatingConfig is already set to true?
What happens in the following race:
resetReadeGroup(a) - start
resetReadeGroup(b) - start
resetReadeGroup(b) - complete
resetReadeGroup(a) - ???
There is no lock between here and the controller. So an order needs to be defined.
timeline.author: tkaitchuck

replies.bodyText: that should not be a problem because the call to controller should include the generation and hence idempotent. So if RG(b) has already completed the call, RG(a) will simply repeat it with the generation that has already been included in controller.
replies.author: shiveshr

replies.bodyText:
Initial config is version 0
resetReadeGroup(a) - Sets flag to 'true'
a is assigned version 1 by the controller.
resetReadeGroup(b)
b is assigned version 2 by the controller.
a unsets the flag and updates the readergroupstate.
b crashes.
Now the controller thinks the version is 2 and the config is b. But the group says A and nobody considers the update ongoing.
replies.author: tkaitchuck

           getThrowingException(controller.updateReaderGroup(scope, groupName, config)); 
        
    
  


controller.updateReadergroup is conditional. it will reject the request from (b) if (a) has already incremented the generation to 1.
and if rg finds the generation on controller ahead of generation in its local state, it should first complete the previously attempted reset and only then should it even attempt the new reset which is to call the controller again to increment the generation.

replies.bodyText:
I think you misunderstand:
Calling update on a state synchronizer will be retried can cause the update function to be re-run if it is not up to date. So it is not necessary to call fetchUpdates between calls to update in a loop because by definition the state will be up to date. That is the contract of the update function. So you can simply remove the fetchUpdates call.
replies.author: tkaitchuck

replies.bodyText: I've moved the synchronizer.fetchUpdates to outside the while loop so its called once before the while loop. Then within the while loop update will allow for the state to be up to date.

timeline.bodyText:
This is storing config which was passed as a parameter. It does not appear to have a generation set on it.
What I see happening now is that resetReaderGroup is called with a config provided by the user. Presumably they don't set the generation. (Should that method be private?) So the default value of -1 is passed. The call ends up here and it passes the config into the state init. But in updateConfigIfNeeded it pulls from the controller which updates the generation id every time. So it will always return a new config. Thus we end up reinitializing the group state twice.
